user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_socket_nonblocking_:
```c
int
MHD_socket_nonblocking_ (MHD_socket sock)
{
#if defined(MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS)
  int flags;

  flags = fcntl (sock,
                 F_GETFL);
  if (-1 == flags)
    return 0;

  if ( ((flags | O_NONBLOCK) != flags) &&
       (0 != fcntl (sock,
                    F_SETFL,
                    flags | O_NONBLOCK)) )
    return 0;
#elif defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  unsigned long flags = 1;

  if (0 != ioctlsocket (sock,
                        (int) FIONBIO,
                        &flags))
    return 0;
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#if defined(MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS)
  int flags;

  flags = fcntl (sock,
                 F_GETFL);
  if (-1 == flags)
    return 0;

  if ( ((flags | O_NONBLOCK) != flags) &&
       (0 != fcntl (sock,
                    F_SETFL,
                    flags | O_NONBLOCK)) )
    return 0;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. All return statements are conditionally reachable at runtime: flags is obtained at runtime and the subsequent if checks may or may not take the return 0 path. The logical AND uses short‑circuit evaluation but does not create statically unreachable code. There is no compile‑time constant or construct forcing any branch to be unreachable in the shown fragment.
